messages.content:
Hey all, I write this question because with @flushthefashion we want to prepare a WordPress plugin that allows one to login using signature provided by the Mina address.

To my understanding, that would require to actually do one of the following:
1. Run o1js in wrapper from within PHP
2. Implement the whole Mina cryptography in PHP from scratch

But maybe I'm wrong. We would like to consult if anyone has other idea. Many thanks in advance!

I built a similar package in c#, https://github.com/youtpout/MinaSignerNet/tree/master/MinaSignerNet

I use a preexisting library for blake2, but I need to reimplement the rest of the functionnalities like poseidon hash, how hash input was build and how to pass from string to bit, it's lot of work but not impossible

embeds.description: Contribute to youtpout/MinaSignerNet development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: This is gold! Thank you!
you are welcome, if you need some help to understand I can assist you
It's very helpful because you identified the bare minimum to make it work.
I just didn't implement signature of zkapp
yes the original library is here https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/tree/main/src/mina-signer

embeds.title: o1js/src/mina-signer at main Â· o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: but they are some reference to external library
I debug in local signature to understand the different process
but you have the verification of the signature, right?
Not for zkapp, only for other functionnalities
Hey, sounds cool. Can I DM you?
yes if it's technical problem a reply in this channel can be a good thing, to share solution with all users
o1js signatures are schnorr signatures over the pasta curves. You may check out the library below for schnorr signatures but it doesn't support pasta curves: https://github.com/fabianfabian/phpecc/
Additionally, you can try to use o1js bindings with webassembly. AFAIK wordpress supports it.

> To my understanding, that would require to actually do one of the following:
> Run o1js in wrapper from within PHP
> Implement the whole Mina cryptography in PHP from scratch

@renzokuken we have a pure TS library called `mina-signer` which implements zkapp signatures. so you'd only need to wrap that instead of o1js. It's much more lightweight

the bare minimum to make it work isn't very small unfortunately:
- scalar multiplication on pallas curve
- poseidon hash in the pallas base field
- serializing a zkapp tx into a list of field elements for hashing
if you want to support classical/mainnet payments as well - they have a different serialization and different set of poseidon parameters

Great to hear everybody's thoughts and feedback on this . IMO if we are looking at large scale adoption through WordPress websites are we realistically too early in development to attempt this? Or alternatively can the steps needed be done in a logical and progressive way. And of course is there an enthusiasm to do it?

Thank you!

I was thinking about wrapping the ts code, but I am not sure if that is a good solution for this use case. @flushthefashion intends it to be used with WordPress, most users of WordPress have cheap hosting and are not able to install sophisticated libraries. Such a wrapper would probably need to be installed as PHP module by the server administrator, most WordPress users don't have such capabilities and even if they do, most of them probably wouldn't manage it technically...
if you don't want to rebuild this part I suggest to create a public rest api with node to validate auth, your php part can easily interact with it

REST API also makes sense to me. Since this is only about verifying signatures there's no privacy concern AFAICT. Someone would need to run the REST server. It shouldn't be very resource heavy - again, `mina-signer` is lightweight and verifying a signature takes maybe 50ms
Based on Gregor's info would you be interested in running the REST server?

Running a verifier is a solution to the problem, but is it a good solution?
1. Think of average WordPress user who runs a website, wants to integrate MINA login and finds out needs to run own server with a verifier software running on it. I used to work as a WooCommerce plugin support engineer, from my experience most WordPress users know how to install simplest plugin, if plugin needs custom module or custom server it is beyond them. I think not many people would use Mina login plugin if it requires a signature verification server.
2. Alternatively someone might provide a public verification server, but I think if defies the point of signature verification login. The biggest advantage of that is, anyone can verify signature independently, suddenly this advantage is not there because user would need to use external server provided by third party to verify the signature...
This is a very common problem, not only in Mina. Cutting edge technologies are developed using newest tools, however, almost entire internet runs on old, outdated tech like PHP.
Sounds like we need mina.php 😄
Good luck to develop it, I need some week to create it in c#

Maybe those methods or their source code can help:
https://docs.aurowallet.com/general/reference/api-reference/methods/mina_verifymessage
https://docs.aurowallet.com/general/reference/api-reference/methods/mina_verifyfields

I don't know much about wordpress nor php, but maybe it would make sense to create a wordpress plugin in php which would run the wasm in some php wasm runtime.

So it would look like this:
1. compile rust verification to wasm
2. run wasm in php using something like this https://github.com/wasmerio/wasmer-php
3. create wordpress plugin that uses 2.

messages.content: Unfortunately AURO canât be used as verifier because its client side. We need verification server side. Also we canât use AURO code because its using the Mina signer JavaScript code.

It is possible to do something similar in PHP, it would be a wrapper. It is possible to wrap Rust, C, Python or JavaScript libraries to be used in PHP. Problem is such wrapper needs to be installed on the server as PHP module. Most Wordpress users donât get admin access on their hosting, they usually use cheap shared hosting solutions which donât allow installation of custom modules (and thus, wrappers).
How do you create the signature you want to verify? It seems, given all the limitations, itâs easier to create a PR to Auro Wallet if you produce the signature with it than port o1js to php
php is supposed to be run on a server
if you would implement it in php how would that work without custom modules?
AURO wallet can be used to produce signature but verification must be done server side using PHP.

Custom libraries that can be just imported and delivered with the plugin are ok, custom modules that need to be installed by server administrator are not (wrappers of code that is not PHP are part of that category).
Auro Wallet supports create signatures and verify signatures, but for some login and other operations, it is better for the server to verify the signature.

What I mean is that instead of porting the o1js signatures code to PHP, you can try to use for Mina Login ECDSA signatures that are also supported by o1js (but not by mina-signer at the moment, as I understand). This way, you can use existing ECDSA PHP libraries and concentrate the development on the web TypeScript code generating the signatures. Still, it seems like the following should be done in this case:
- PR for mina-signer to support ECDSA
- PR for Auro Wallet to support ECDSA through mina-signer
- Mapping of the Mina and ECDSA private keys

I'm not sure it is possible to do, but if it is, it will probably be easier than porting o1js native signatures to PHP, given the limitation on the custom modules.

Really good to see all the thoughts and discussions, love the community sharing and spirit! Let's keep this conversation going. According to Google there are 800+ million WordPress websites out there. If we seriously want Mina to gain traction easy adoption by this huge audience can be a very big part of the puzzle.
That is interesting, if AURO supports ECDSA over some commonly used curve such as secp256k1 then definitely easily doable in PHP. @flushthefashion
I don't think Auro supports ECDSA, but given that there is o1js support, it is probably possible to add.
Would be interested in your feedback @niuniu | Auro Wallet
Having the ability to use Auro Wallet on Ethereum to build zkApps that use both chains - Mina and Ethereum is even more interesting))
Yeah, I think it's also easy to live in a web3 bubble, real world solutions that touch web2 users are essential for growth.

https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/ecdsa
like this `ECDSA - API`?
But the algorithm currently used by mina-signer is `Schnorr`. Does php have `Schnorr`?

messages.content:
Whether its ECDSA or Schnorr it is not difficult. Problem is which curve and hashing algorithm is used.

It is easy to do as long as there is no need to implement Field and Poseidon hashing.

Here are my own tutorials, ECDSA:
https://mareknarozniak.com/2021/03/16/ecdsa/

Schnorr:
https://mareknarozniak.com/2021/05/25/schnorr-signature/

embeds.description: Introduction and a toy example of ECDSA signature

embeds.title: Schnorr Signature
embeds.description: Visual tutorial on performing Schnorr multi-signatures

messages.content:
There is already a pure TS implementation of ecdsa over any curve in o1js, it would be very easy to add that to mina-signer.

It's also easy to use the Mina private key as a ecdsa private key (private keys are really just long numbers).

However, does this fulfill the original goal? Wasn't the idea to login with signatures that can be verified to belong to someone's Mina address? Since the Mina address is a public key on a different curve, there's no way for a verifier to connect ecdsa signatures back to that address
Take my c# and ask gpt to translate it, is not very big
Yes, but as gregor said, the address is definitely an issue. Maybe WebAssembly compiling `mina-signer` is indeed an idea
Can we build a team to do it?

I don't think webassembly is a solution unfortunately... The shared hostings most WordPress users have probably does not support execution of webassembly bytecode, also even if it does, its configuration will not allow a PHP script to execute it for security reasons (disadvantage of shared hosting).
I asked few PHP developers I know if they would be willing to help you and rewrite the C# module by @Youtpout.
That's great. 🙌

What about Schnorr's protocol? This would only require you to implement a subset of the cryptography we use (namely finite fields and basic elliptic curve operations, no hashing, no map to group/field) and it would still prove knowledge of the private key that belongs to some public key

I think also hashing is required - server will provide a challenge to sign, a string like "login to <website> on <datetime>". Not sure if it is relevant if it is Poseidon or not, probably not because we are not signing field but just regular arbitrary bytestring.
You can just sample a random challenge
From protocol perspetive yes, however for user experience I believe human readable would be better.
or just encode the string into field elements
you could also use pretty much any hash function for that, doesn't need to be Poseidon over the field i think

Preferably, should be same hashing algorithm as the one used in here: https://docs.aurowallet.com/general/reference/api-reference/methods/mina_signmessage#request

So wallet would get a string to sign and server should be able to come up with same digest of same string.

messages.content: I used BigInteger type in C#, because I can store field and other type directly in it and I don't need to create custom type

> Preferably, should be same hashing algorithm as the one used in here: 
btw, @renzokuken, I wouldn't use `signMessage()`. It's a method from mainnet times and uses the old, less efficient and deprecated Poseidon parameters. We still use them for payment signatures for compatibility, but for anything new I'd use `signFields()` which uses the new parameters. Small bonus is that they could also be verified in an o1js circuit.

I would be interested to set up a group/team to investigate the feasibility of integrating a Mina wallet with WordPress. I think it can open a huge door to adoption. @teddy would love to get your feedback on whether it could potentially by something eligible for a core grant?
Implementing Mina-signer in PHP sounds incredibly painful but also very fun 😅 happy to help!
No pain, no gain!
